Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: The Impact of Trauma on Economic Preferences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this RAPID project, the Principal Investigators will examine the effects of trauma from the violence of war on risk aversion and other economic attitudes by conducting economic experiments in Afghanistan. The team has preliminary results showing that Afghans who live near a bombing site, when primed to recall a fearful event, are willing to pay far more for certainty in an economic trade-off than is predicted by mainstream economic theory. This project will extend this work to examine the effects of trauma on all of the "Big 5" core factors that significantly shape economic behavior: tolerance for risk, patience and time discounting, social preferences, competitive propensity, and strategic sophistication. These changes in economic attitude can turn individuals away from otherwise beneficial economic opportunities and, society-wide, harm prospects for recovery.

In terms of broader impacts, this research will reveal how exposure to violence can dramatically influence many aspects of an individual's economic decision making. The project will also attempt to demonstrate the potential for simple economic instruments to act as diagnostic tools for economists and policy makers to identify potentially at-risk individuals, especially in transitional economies. While conducted with Afghans, these experiments may shed light on the effects of trauma on anyone exposed to violence, including members of the U.S. military and victims of violent crime. More broadly, this work may show shifts in economic attitudes that can have implications for the development and economic growth prospects of war-torn societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project is to explore the effects of exposure to trauma on economic behavior.    A primary  study of Afghan civilians yielded a set of interesting results. The primary findings are that Afghan civilians who live in more historically violent neighborhoods exhibit a different shape of risk preferences when reminded of violent episodes. Such individuals hold on to certainty in a manner that is inconsistent with Expected Utility theory. That direct preferences for certainty may be linked to life experience, and triggered by recollection presents a potentially important consequence of violent exposure. A manuscript has been completed focused on the civilian data and submitted. This manuscript is now accepted for publication at the American Economic Review.

A related research effort sought to examine similar patterns of behavior with college students at American University of Afghanistan. Two project staff traveled to Kabul, Afghanistan for an 8 day research trip. The purpose of the visit was to meet officials of the American University of Afghanistan and begin setting up a proposed experimental economics laboratory. Prior to the research trip, an on-line recruitment effort for acquiring subjects was conducted. A database was created of over 150 potential subjects and a recruitment website remains active and accessible through the American University of Afghanistan Website. This portion of the project demonstrated that it is potentially feasible to conduct economics experiments in Afghanistan in a similar fashion to those conducted in Western samples, but pilot experiments did not yield usable data. Due to recent security issues the project's geographical focus has moved away from Afghanistan to Pakistan.
